Perhaps I'm looking at this wrong, but the fact that things can indeed change means that there must be a progression, in the case of Planck states from one to the the next. In other words, the "movement" from one Planck state to the next is simply another way to understand time. You could expand the idea of Planck states to an analogy of seconds; each second frozen in time. The only difference is of course the length of a second vs a Planck second. Remember, our perception is our reality.

You're looking it at from the wrong perspective, and that's why you're having a hard time imaginating "motion" in a "timeless" universe. But you must understand that we're not "moving" through the Plank units. We feel like we do because we can remember the past. We feel like things are moving and changing around us because we can remember how things were different a second ago. But actually we live in "frozen Plank units" and each of the "you" in those plank units believes time is moving.

The "concept of time" is very real because the laws of physics are very real. But time is a physical concept used to give meaning to physical equations, but it's not a reality. Einstein said it himself: "Time is an illusion". He understood that fact. On the other hand, the bigger question is not "why we were given time", but "why does the universe exist at all"?

However, for something to change from one Planck state to another requires time itself. Change requires time. A world of flatlanders existing in two dimensions of space and none of time would be static. The Planck second is too small by itself for anything to take place above the level of quantum fluctuation, and certainly not macroscopically. In addition, relativity treats time as an additional dimension. This is recognized by Stephen Hawking, Michio Kaku, J. Richard Gott, and originally Alber

According to Rob Bryanton (Writer of Imagining the Tenth Dimension, and impressive book) time does not exist actually so there's no need for anything to create it. Time is an illusion that comes from our brain perceiving the changes from one Plank state to the next. The universe timeline is made up of frozen Plank states, we just think we are "moving" through them because we can remember the past. But there's actually no "motion" in the first place.

It depends on which definition of theory you're using, the popular definition, or the scientific.
